Many call themselves feminists – and then leave it at the staged self-image and, when it really matters, cowardly sneak away and leave their sisters alone in need. The term feminist becomes a proudly worn label. We like to move with the times, but less like to take to the streets as demonstrators, and we even less like to stand up for female victims of male violence.
Every year again... we celebrate Feminist Struggle Day! If you still want to buy cleaning supplies, cosmetics, chocolates or diapers, this is the day for them. Because only on March 8th are all these and other products reduced. Although in principle there is nothing wrong with colorful nail polish or delicious chocolates, this commercialization mistakenly turns the feminist struggle day into something “apolitical”. It thus robs it of its meaning and reinforces all the gender stereotypes that need to be fought anyway.
Many feminist demands are decades, sometimes even centuries old, and some of them are no less relevant today than they were then. But it takes courage to address gender discrimination, global hate crimes against women, and the social injustice that goes with it. Because after that it is no longer possible to see the world with the same eyes.
Because regardless of whether we describe ourselves as political or apolitical: abstention is also a political decision.
We don't need "girl power", we need real solidarity among each other. A feminist association that demands its rights shoulder to shoulder and translates these demands and wishes into its own life. An association that stands by and supports each other in solidarity.
We live in times of war unilaterally declared by men against us, sisters.
They humiliate us, they abuse us, they kill us, they rape us, they enslave us, they force us to give birth, they force us to marry them, they sentence us to death, they lynch us for disobeying. They want us weak, defenseless, dependent on them, hungry, they want us anxious, sad, tired, docile, without the right to a life of our own, equal education, equal pay, equal civil and human rights, without the right to our own sexuality, without rights to one's own body. They don't want to accept us as human beings, they don't want to grant us equal rights, no real freedom, no self-determined and non-violent life. Open your eyes sisters and don't be silent any longer, for together we are strong.
-Anita Kanitz trade unionist

The Duden defines sexism as the "idea that one gender is inherently superior to the other, and the discrimination, oppression, neglect and disadvantage of people, especially women, because of their gender, which is considered justified."
Sexist violence is therefore the form of violence that is based on the assumption that men are naturally superior to women. This form of violence against women based on their gender can be found both in analogue and digital form.
Degradation, threats, sexual harassment, and misogynistic comments are just a few examples of forms of sexist digital violence. There is also image-based sexual abuse, in which nude photos of (in most cases, but not exclusively) women and girls are created or stolen and uploaded to porn sites without their consent. The threat of sexual offenses is also a widespread form of sexist digital violence.
Intimidation and silencing are not unique features of sexist digital violence. Men and non-binary people are also actively pushed out of the discourse in certain debates. What is striking, however, is how strategically women are to be silenced - especially when they want to draw attention to social or political injustices. Women in public life are particularly often the target of organized hate campaigns. Hate comments are directed against their appearance (“You are ugly”), their sexuality (“Nobody wants you, that's why you're single”) or their emotionality (“You are hysterical”). They are also threatened with gender-based violence (“you should be raped”) or “given their places” (“go back to the kitchen where you belong”). All of these examples are gender specific and have nothing to do with the actual discourse.
Little is said about the digital side of violence - harassment and harassment are increasingly shifting to the internet. However, the Internet also offers ways to defend yourself.
Many offenses in the area of ​​digital violence are not reported - for various reasons. In the case of sexual harassment, for example, the number of unreported cases is generally high - online and offline.

Therefore, our request is simple and straightforward, we demand some compensating acts from a couple of companies that had acted rashly when the Op-ed came out to immediately cut off any relationship with Johnny Depp back in 2018/2019.

Disney's action of cutting off Johnny Depp from the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise and Fantastic Beast franchise not only impacted Johnny Depp but the audience around the world. We, the audience, had high expectations towards the character and Disney should also be responsible to us, as it is us who led to Disney's success, without audience support for Disney's product, Disney would not have come to the current stage. Therefore, we would demand a public apology made by Disney regarding its reckless act against Johnny Depp. 

Second, since the trial came out as Amber Heard did defame Johnny Depp in the Washington post's Op-ed, we would demand Washington Post take down the article at once to prevent the spreading of misleading information.

Third, we would also demand that L'Oréal, which Amber has been their global ambassador since 2018 end their partnership to clarify that they are not in support of any aspersive influencer.

Fourth, both ACLU (American Civil Liberties Union) and OHCHR (Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights) should take down her position as ambassador for women's rights and Human Rights Champion.

 

We hope by signing this petition, at least we can bring Johnny Depp his justice back, and show him that the world now knows the truth and that society will not let him down once again.
